posts.cooked: Do we think that a thrifty elevator run by two ~12:1 reduction neos could lift a ~120 pound robot for shallow climb? This assumes some sort of climb built onto elevator.

posts.name: Kieran Jarvis
posts.cooked: Our 2025 elevator has an 8.2:1 reduction with two neos and fairly large HTD-8 pulleys, and we are able to deep climb off it. Robot weighed about 105lbs IIRC, including Bumpers and battery. You may need an engageable ratchet or latch to sustain the climb for three seconds after losing motor power, even with motors in brake.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: We are going to do something similar. We have 20:1 gearboxes with the same elevator, and one of our mentors (mech engineer at Clemson) helped me calculate if we would have the torque and it is actually insane the amount of safety factor we had. I am not qualified to do the calculations by hand but quickly running the numbers through a calculator shows you should be fine as long as your mechanical design of the climber attachment is strong enough.
Do you have some sort of ratcheting mech?

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: We do not. We haven’t really considered that being an issue, but brake mode on the gearboxes should be enough in combination of how high up we lift up.
Makes sense, thank you so much!

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: I recommend you check the numbers with ambcalc.com/mechanism . That will tell you how much current you’ll need to apply in order to lift the robot, and how much voltage you’ll need to hold it up (anything around ~1V should hold at the end of the match). If you have questions about how to use it, feel free to send me a PM.
